These are 90 degree brackets for 2020 aluminium extrusion. They provide rather strong and stiff connections. They only need 20% infill to be effective although I printed with 2mm shell on all sides and print in ABS. There is two versions. The one without the notch is for joining extrusions where they have slots meet and the notch has the corner removed for situations where that is needed. I use a M5 x 10mm cap screw with matching T-nuts to attach this bracket.
The design works well for the pre assembly t-nuts and for the post assembly t-nuts needs a fraction shaved off the slot edges to allow the nuts to rotate into position. I will likely fix that later with a new stl version. Updated to fix an error with a mismatch in the bolt countersink on the two sides of the version with the corner notch. The filename is now "cnr_bracket_strong_braced_notch_fixed.stl", Accidentally uploaded the wrong file last time.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Print in ABS or stronger material.
I used supports from bed only and sliced in cura.

I designed this thing in openscad.  This is my second version since I made an earlier one but that was a little too flexible even printed at 100% infill so for this one I added more triangulation  in different directions and thicken the brace up. Interestingly It doesn't use much more plastic than the original did at 100% fill but 20% fill on this design is sufficient.
I will upload the scad file when I get a chance to clean it up.

comments.text:
No apologies necessary. Thanks again for saving me all that time.
I've opened the inner and outer holes slightly, as well as decreased the width slightly of the keyed slots. This greatly improved post-processing time, as previously everything needed to be drilled/dremelled. I can send these back to you if you want to include in the download.
Also, I've gone ahead and added a 1cm cubed magnet into the brace, and accompanying magnetic knob designed to be affixed to plastic sheeting. This allows 2020 enclosures to be encased with insulating plastic sheets (lexan/acrylic), and easily removed with a pull. I'll put these up shortly as a remix.

These fuel rail cover letters are about 1/16" thick and will set in the recess area of the fuel rails on 1999-2004 Corvettes with the LS1 engine. I sprayed primer and then painted mine with rustoleum brushed nickel spray paint. This is the same color as I used on the fuel rail covers when I spayed a carbon fiber look on them using rubber shelf-protector sheets to give it that checkered look. I found this video on youtube describing how to achieve the look. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7N5N-AYaENI

title: LCD V2 case with feet- Printrbot Metal Simple

description.text:
I was unhappy with the standard printed case that Printrbot suggests for the LCD v2 (with card reader).  Moving my metal simple with hits heated bed, associated big power supply and the non-attached LCD screen was just ridiculous.  Buying an extension for the power supply solved one problem (can now disconnect the power from the pigtail rather than from the board itself), but I needed to attach the LCD.  I found several options and ended up remixing this case with a shortened version of the pedestal stands I found in THIS model:    LCD Screen Printbot metal simple, by vincentjalink.  
Because I wanted a good connection between the front foot/stand and the LCD case, I changed where the split in the case happened- it's now parallel with the face/screen.  The board affixes to the face with 4 m3 screws that I had lying around- *Note: I had to tap out the holes- consider enlarging a wee bit!
The lid/face is a nice tight snap fit to the base, with slots for a screwdriver, should you ever need to pop it apart again.  I used hot glue in the slots for the feet to make sure they stayed put.  You could probably tinker and make a better friction fit, but I didn't feel the need.
If you are struggling to edit meshes, Autodesk 123D Design (free!) will now convert meshes to solids!  This is by FAR the easiest and cheapest way I have found to remix.

comments.text: NOTE: There are two small spacers that print along with the Face- I meant to revise and delete them- they were meant to fit between the two circuit boards on the LCD, but are too large.  You don't need them anyway.  I suggest splitting the print into separate objects in your build software (Cura will do this) and then just delete them.  Sorry!

title: Assorted Mounts for MPCNC Universal Mounting System

description.text: UPDATE: These designs are obsolete, or at the very least, very dated. I would recommend checking to see if anyone has made something more recent. I don't think these will fit properly in the current universal mounts for the 525 and other versions of the MPCNC. UPDATE: After using the v4 of the DW660 mount for a while, I have added a one-piece v5 version. It is much more rigid and easier to put on/take off than the two piece version. Unfortunately, it has to be printed with support, but once it's cleaned up, it's a much better mount. UPDATE: Added requested mount for 300W spindle. UPDATE: The DW660 mount is now at v4. I had to create some clearance for the router on the lower mount. UPDATE: I did not like how low my original DW660 mount (QR_660_v2.stl) positioned the tool, so I made a new one that places the tool higher and closer to the x-y axes. The new QR_660_v3.stl uses both the upper 660 clamp and the kt_660_spindle_clamp. It can be used with PCFlyer's dust shoe. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1091450 for more details. I have not finished printing or trying this yet. I'll post pictures when I do.

These are various mounts designed to work with HicWic's universal mounting system for the MPCNC. 
I printed the receiver part in PLA, and everything else in ABS at .3 layer height, between 50% and 70% infill. The tolerances are very exacting for this system, and I had to use a swiss file and acetone to get everything to fit together smoothly. It took a while, but it wasn't hard, and now everything goes together great. Very solid but easy to slide on and off. I will add more photos once I get the system mounted on my MPCNC and get the various tools installed on their mounts.
Note that the DW660 mount uses the part "660_upper_clamp" for both the upper and lower mounts, so print two of them. The pen holder is designed to hold a standard sharpie marker. Use the "kt_sharpie_cap" and some rubber bands to apply downward pressure on the pen. Again, I'll post pics once I get everything set up.
Thanks to HicWic for a well-designed universal mounting system, and as always, a big thanks to Ryan for the MPCNC! Learn more about the MPCNC at vicious1.com.

title: Spool Arm to fit CTC / Flashforge Printer walls

description.text: Nice fitting strong spool arm to go on CTC and Flashforge style Replicator clones, with the round holes in the back. Some of the clones are now shipping without any kind of spool arms for the back. Most of the printable ones are junk. Too weak, or bulky or just bad fits. This arm will fit closely to the printer, seal the hole completely, and support the heavy filament spools without issue. Parametric model, so you can make it whatever length you want. We designed this as a simple closed (as in no hole through the center) spool arm to minimize the opening in our Replicator style printers, when we enclosed them with our acrylic enclosures. Details on the enclosures and printer arms can be seen at: http://drazzticaction.com/products-page-2/3dprinters/ Enjoy

Printer:

Flashforge creator X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.27 or standard

Infill:

none

Notes: Prints horizontal with no raft or support. Has internal structure for strength. Prints with zero fill, 2 shells.
Installation Inserts at an angle an rotates down to lock into position. Two small protrusions to the bottom. Sleek, simple and effective. Enjoy.
Designed in OpenSCAD to be parametric and easily customized. You can change the length diameter, and the thickness of the mating printer wall.

Made to mount a Busch&Mueller D-Toplight Rear Light on my Pletscher Orion Carrier.
It's not perfect or extremely beautiful, but it works! I used 2 M4x8 Hex-Screws to mount the plate to the light and one M3x10 to fix the plate on the carrier. The plate slides into the grooves on the carrier, and the M3-screw keeps it in place to prevent thieves from quickly pulling the light out and take it with them.
Of course i also replaced the lever that clamps the carrier to the seat post with an M6 hex screw (think it was M6x45) so nobody steals the complete assembly without proper tools.

My printer doesn't like any resistance on the filament roll, so I made some changes to allow the use of a 608 bearing in place of the printed roller. In the next version I'll make it a little curvier, and modify to use less plastic. v2 released! Made it a little curvier. Doesn't really do anything except make it slightly more aesthetically appealing. (Very slight improvement, lets be honest)
Added a boss to prevent the bearings from touching the back surface. Also allows for easier removal of the bearings if you need to replace the base.
Extended the base 1cm for more stability on soft surfaces, like carpet.
Made the groove on the bearing cover (I really need a better name) slightly deeper.

description.text:
Ever wanted to learn to model in 3D specifically for print? Ever wanted to see practical examples?
From time to time I do something and I feel I wanted to share the info so that others might also find it useful....hence this thing.. For example I needed to make a ball joint for a project. Rather than just share the ball joint only I share how I made it. So this thing will be a Work in progress thing. you can call it a class which will also be located here
http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL7tGtxtIW0IyVtwssAA4hnMOpObYDKaWT But think of new people just getting into 3D printing and wanting to know how to model.. They don't go to Youtube right away.. they come to thingiverse download models and look at how they are made,,,so that would be an interesting thing to make for them. A thing that teaches you to make things. So enjoy the first project. Follow this thread if you want to stay ahead of any new things you can make. Widgets and whatnots.... And if you have ideas for things or examples post them here. Look to the instruction area for the projects.

comments.text: the problem im running into is when i make my thing and go export it a a stl when i pull it up in my printing softwear (m3d) it doesnt show it on the printer bed does anyone know why??
comments.author: Tobm

comments.text:
What's happening is the the model is too small for you to see because of difference in scale between blender and m3d. This happens because stl format doesn't define any scale, the program that opens the file assumes a scale. e.g. Cura, M3d and other programs may all assume a different base unit. I found that importing into Cura for example I had to scale my blender exported stl file by 100,000 for it to appear the correct size. If you know the program you will be importing your stl file into you could export your stl file at a scale to compensate for this, but this requires you to know what the scale difference would be.
The short answer is just try scaling up your model in the printing software until you can see it, or create a model of a known size e.g. 10cm x 10cm and import it, then you will be able to easily see what the scale difference is. The scaling can be done in blender when you export to stl, or in the printing software normally you can use a scale tool to increase the size of the model. You might need to zoom in first to see it because it's probably a tiny dot.

I have 2.67 and 2.68 I prefer 2.65 only because they changed much of my hotkeys without much notice.. Basically crippling Maya hotkey users that use laptops..    The print tools are great for previewing issues for those that use slicing programs that see self intersecting geometry and have issues with it but does nothing to fix those issues.  I will show what the issue looks like, how to prevent it, and how to fix it for those that use self-intersecting slicing programs.     For those that do use makerware I would say always union you models in the end, and model with slow kidgloves.  Makerware always was a pain with models when I had one.   For those that use slic3r it is pretty much a free for all and let creativity fly.   In the end you'll need to do some cleanup to make it universal ;)  Netfab does a pretty good job,  Netfab pro does fix the internal faces with a couple buttons...

title: parametric bed mounts for delta printer

description.text:
Adaptable bed mounts for a round glass bed mounted on the beam base of a delta printer.
Enter the bed diameter, beam dimensions, measure the distance to the "completed triangle" of the frame base (details in the SCAD file comments).
Set the height of the retainer wall to accommodate the bed height i.e. plain glass or with insulator/heater/spreader/glass.
I've commented the SCAD pretty thoroughly so users can adapt as they need. Suggestions for improvements are welcome.
"Parametric_bed_mount" has a tab hanging under the bottom of the mount to make best use of print space height, but prints on its back edge and doesn't lend itself to a nice clean print.
"beam_top" version loses some print space height but prints flat really nicely, also has a much stronger support for the bed, especially if heated (I'd worry about the "tab" bending under a heated bed on the other version).
Both versions can be used with FSRs held under the bed with 3M double-sided adhesive tabs.
Included STLs are for a 240mm bed (pyrex disk came out of a silicone-sided cake pan) on a base of 270mm 15x15 OpenBeam extrusions, joined by Johann's laser cut aluminum corner brackets.

title: Lever for Operant Chamber
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Lever for the Operant Conditioning Chamber. First look at the Operant Conditioning Chamber: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1226076 Print the parts using PLA because it is a non-toxic material. A layer height of 0.2 mm is recommended. Most parts can be printed with a 20% fill density. However, “bumper.stl” must be printed with 100% fill density. This part counterbalances the weight of the lever and must be heavy. No support material in necessary. You will need also the following materials: 1 Stainless steel metal plate (gauge no. 16). I like to use a steel lever because rats occasionally chew the lever. If this is not a problem in your application, you could print the file "Lever.stl" and use a PLA lever. My recommendation is to ask a CNC cutter service to make a stainless steel plate for you. The dimensions can be found in the image inside the Plate.zip file. Note that all the measures are in millimeters. 1 Snap action switch. The “switch.stl” file was designed specifically to hold a Honeywell 311SM4-T switch. These switches are very precise and the lever was calibrated using these switches. I got them from Mouser Electronics (part # 785-311SM4-T). www.mouser.com. 2 – # 4 x 1/2 in. Metal Flat Phillips Screw. These screws attach the section with the switch to the body of the lever enclosure. 1 - M3 x 20 mm Brass Threaded Stand-Off Hex Screw Pillars with Nut. It is used to hold the metal lever in place. 6 - M3 x 10 mm Screws. Two scres keep the lever attached to the panel of the chamber. Two screws are used to adjust the length of the lever, and one more is required to limit the vertical movement of the lever. E6000 Glue. This is necessary to attach the part in the "bumper.stl" file to the actual lever. Use the images to assemble the lever. 3D printed parts are blue, metal parts (metal plate and stand off) are white, screws are black, and the switch is brown.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 PLA Model

author: RogerEsc

description.text:
Hello Again! If you are a mini fantatic then this is for you.. I have here a 3D printed mini wheel inspired speaker (6 inch splits) cover for minis and any other car where people like those wheels. In Australia they are called kidney wheels. Newer wheels made by Rota look like this also a bit. The red mini cooper s was my very first mini cooper s, I still drive a mini but the BMW ones. The photo of the two people is of me and my very good friend Jack Read who was a very famous mini mechanic in Australia.
I had the luck of meeting Jack at the age care facility where my father in law was admitted to, they became friends before I got to meet Jack.
Jack had dementia like my father in law but could recite engine part numbers from the top of his head and tell me how to fix minis as well as play chess brilliantly. He passed away late last year but we shared many mini stories and I gave him the very first set of these wheel covers to remind him about minis.
We also watched the original italian job movie with michael caine from time to time and we shared soft drinks and pavlova (aussie desert).
I miss both Jack and my father in law a lot and this little project is a great way for me to share Jack's passion and love for mini cars. this was jack:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1ecImTg7xM4 I found an old mini clubman parked on my street and looked so well kept, I had to go back inside and give him a set i had printed already with a little note.
when I got back he had left me a reply note on my windscreen also on my BMW MINI which was parked across the road.
the other red mini in the photos was my first mini cooper s.
I have owned now 7 minis in my lifetime!! Anyway enjoy and post photos when done

A token stand for Eldrich Horror or Arkham Horror monster tokens.
I got tired of the ones that came with the game tearing up the bottom of the tokens, so I made my own that allow you to slide the token in rather than wedge it between 3 pins. I have also made a similar stand for the character tokens (please see other items uploaded by me).

Printrbot

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Infill:

Notes: I do not have a heated bed, so the use of a raft makes that a bit easier. Blue painter's tape usually works, however in this case it tended to fail around layer 2 or 3. The part is more or less solid, so infill and wall thickness are mostly irreverent.

Simple not simplistic I just started with a very simple squared off frame and added feet. Aesthetically I rounded nearly ever corner and for functionality added chamfers to allow easier loading of the character piece. A simple and straight forward solution to an issue that had been bugging me since I bought the Arkham Horror game years ago.

Flush Fitting camera mount for the CMOS 700 V2 Camera as supplied in many Fatshark kits, the base on this has no incline to it, (its flat). I haven't yet tested the mount on a quad, however, its a very strong protective case, which shouldn't be visible in the footage. If it is, ill modify it slightly. I have mounted mine using double-sided tape and a zip tie for security.
The dimensions L x W x H are 35mm x 40.5mm x 25mm, this lets it sit snugly under 25mm decks. The mount weighs 6 grams. Please note: This Case is quite a tight fit, it requires a fair amount of force to remove and install the camera

title: PS3 game consoles repair parts /  connector pad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A typical user experience for PS3 gaming consoles, which "gets crazy" after having been used for some time. Issue: PS3 gaming console hits its buttons random when tilting and shaking
Cause: A connector pad inside the console gets aged, loosed and losing elasticity
Possible solution: Decrease the gap between the pad slot and the PCB by inserting an added 3D printed pad. My way: Thanks to the Flexible PLA filament, offering elasticity for the 1.3mm thick pad. It is suggested to slow down to 10mm/s or the filament might get jammed by the extruder stepper motor.

title: Whiteboard Marker / Pen Holder (For laser cutter or CNC Mill) (Java-language parametric)

description.text:
Java-generated whiteboard marker holder meant for laser cutting or CNC milling.
Works by hanging off a screw or also works fine free-standing because it has a wider base.
Holds 9 large markers and 2 small ones, but it's trivial to edit the SVG and change this to make it hold whatever you want. I cut another version of this that is freestanding and holds test tubes, for instance. The slots in the SVG file are sized to print with a snap-fit on a laser cutter with 0.2mm kerf. (In my case, a 60W epilog). You can change the variable in the included stand-alone java file to generate with whatever kerf you'd like, or disable this feature entirely. Would also be easy to CNC mill this from a board by feeding the svg into something like http://www.makercam.com/

comments.text: Beautiful design, would be very handy in the classroom!

title: Mac Pro Mini Replica Case for NUC BRIX or Raspberry Pi

description.text:
This is a proof of concept design for turning an Intel NUC or Gigabyte Brix computer into a replica mini version of a 2013 Mac Pro.  I designed the overall shape but no cut outs or internal structures yet, as I have to acquire the motherboard and fine tune the design to fit.  
If anyone with one of these boards wants to download and remix the design, have at!  Finished height would be about 8" by 4.75"  Just enough for the board, an extra SSD or laptop HDD and top and bottom fans to mimic the downdraft cooling effect of a real mac.  I designed the fan cowl with an apple logo insert that would look cool drilled out and fitted with an LED to serve as a power light.  I might modify this file later with cutout molded in.
Scaled down this would be a cool case for a raspberry pi or other on-chip mini computer board.  Just be sure to scale all parts equally.
By request I added the original 123dx files for editing.
Please respect creative commons rights. you may download, modify and change any part of this design for PERSONAL use but please ask permission before reselling printed copies of this design, in part, whole or as part of another design, for profit.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

40% for shell 70% for base and fan cowl

Notes: I printed the fan cowl and base in carbon fiber PLA and will print the shell in black PLA. Finshed prints are sanded, filled where needed and primed. base will be painted in carbon black flat paint. Shell and fan cowl will be lacquered black. Fan cowl will have LED set into apple logo insert as a 'power on' light.

author: veeresh

description.text: For programming the AVR ATtiny45 and ATtiny85 microcontrollers from Atmel without any additional circuitry or components. This acts like a USBtinyISP (http://ladyada.net/make/usbtinyisp/) but provides an 8-pin socket for placing the ATtiny45/85 directly into the programmer. The firmware is a combination of USBtiny (http://dicks.home.xs4all.nl/avr/usbtiny/) and V-USB (http://www.obdev.at/products/vusb/index.html).

description.text:
A simple clamp for 12mm Rod or linear rails, basically the same dimensions as the aluminium one available on aliexpress apart from a different clamping method.
There are two versions, one with fixed mounting holes and one with slotted holes for adjustment

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: I printed these with 2mm outer shells for strength so could get away with 20% internal fill
Insert a M4 injection nut into the hole in the top with a soldering iron or similar
I designed this in openscad.  When I get time I will put up the scad file.
Due to mounting a gimbal, we recognized a need for a "high" landing gear. Due to its size (i.e., to make it printer friendly) it was splitted in half. Thus, you need to print four (4) of these.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Protos

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter
Parts can be assembled by mounting small pieces of filament into the holes and by glueing pieces afterwards. In addition you might want to stabilize the legs by adding carbon fibre rods.

This is a small attachment point that was made to replace the cheap styrene version in the pole pocket of the vertical blinds in our rental house.   These blinds were all broken at the hole and repeatedly falling off; and had been turned upside down so that there was something for the clip to grab onto.   The only problem was that if you even brushed against them, they would come right off again.   These blinds are common in apartments and rental homes, so maybe someone else can use this piece to fix their mess too. 
Part is printed in black ABS, no brim or supports required.  High detail took a little over 7 minutes for a single unit.

LulzBot

High

author: veeresh

description.text:
This is a case for the Gadgets3D LCD SDcard controller.  
You can use this on any 3D printer. On the back there are inserts for some hooks. The hook has a 7mm gap for 6mm plywood or some thing else to hang it on.  
I designed it for my self sourced Ultimaker.

Print it with a 0.8mm wall thickness. Infill of 20%. Speed and layer height what you want. For the best result a 0.1mm layer height is re-commanded. Make sure that the top front face and bottom back face is laid down on the bed. So you don't have overhangs. If you printed it search some thin 2mm screws with a head of +/- 4mm. Minimal length 10mm. Place the LCD controller on the top part. Place the bottom part on the top part en insert the screws.
That's all.

title: Pan, tilt and roll camera pod for FPV.

description.text:
EDIT - 27.01.2016
Added a plate for single cam with a platform for mounting a Mobius action cam on top.

EDIT - 06.01.2016
I added a plate for a single cam. Roll03.stl.

My take on a pan/tilt/roll camera mount for two 1/3" Sony CCD cams. The camera plate will probably need to be adapted to your camera(s), or use rollblank.stl as a start to make your own plate. Just load the STL into your CAD software or make a new plate from scratch. It is designed to hold two cameras rotated 90° for my DIY goggles. My cameras will mount with double sided tape.
Designed around two Hitec HS-225MG/BB and one HS-65HB servo. The flanges fit these servos directly. 
Requires one 3x10x4 mm ball bearing and one M3x12 screw in addition to self tapping screws for the servos (without grommets).

Supports:

No

Notes: Print with max 0.5 mm extrusion width (preferably smaller) and no more than 0.2 mm layer height for all the servo flange to come out ok. The flanges don't have to be perfect to work. Print as they open. I didn't use supports on any parts. The tilt piece has a large bridged area but it should print ok. If the first bridge layer is a mess just trim afterwards.

title: Microswitch end stop bracket for z-axis

description.text: A bracket to assemble a microswitch for the Z-axis. Microswitches have such small holes that they are difficult to secure. So I designed this mini bracket to fix the problem. Just push a standard Microswitch in the bracket and secure it with some double sided tape to your printer. Slowly I am improving my DLP printer by replacing the DIY parts with more precise printed parts printed by the printer itself.

description.text:
This is a battery charge indicator that you can make and then stick on  a battery. It works very simply: you slide the little indicator over to either the charged side or discharged side depending on the status of the battery. If you don't want to make the part out of three different colours then thats no problem because I have put a tick and a cross on either side so you will still know whether the battery is charged. 
I printed out of PLA using a layer height of 0.1mm and an infill of 100% but infill doesn't really matter. 
This indicator does require assembly as it is made in three parts but this is easy. Simply put the slider indicator in one half and then stick the other half directly next to it on the battery so that the slider can slide between the two halves. To stick the indicator down onto the battery (and thus together) you can use double sided tape or regular all purpose glue.

An Egyptian Pharaoh of the 18th dynasty, King Tutankhamun is known as the great child king, having assumed the throne of Egypt at around the age of 9 or 10. He died young, presumably around the age of 18, but his legend has lived on. This model is of the funeral mask he was found wearing when his tomb was discovered by Howard Carter in 1925. It is one of most well known artifacts to have come out of Ancient Egypt.

Notes: Printed initially using Solutech PLA Real Gold, but it tends to get stuck up in the nozzle so after the print got to 20% completion I aborted and printed using Hatchbox PLA Yellow, it printed with absolutely no problems at 45% original scale.

Sketchup I found a model that was posted online to the Trimble 3D warehouse by 'Brundiseinsis' back in 2012 (https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html id=8c8df1fa386504db6dab6933c92047a5). I used this model as the basis for my work. I downloaded it and put it into Sketchup Make. Once there I looked the model over and made necessary changes that would cause it to be easier to print ultimately. I looked for small or incomplete features that could be improved on or removed, overlapping polygons, etc. Once I was satisfied with the new model I exported it to an STL file. Sketchup View, Original Model NetFabb Pro Once I had the STL file created through Sketchup I put it into NetFabb. Generally the STL files created by Sketchup have a lot of errors in them that need fixed. I ran a customized fix on the model, and noticed for some reason it had flipped all the polygons backwards so I had to flip all of them to the correct orientation. Once I had this step completed I checked to be sure there were few errors and with that taken care of I exported the newly repaired file into a new STL. NetFabb View Meshmixer With the STL file I created through NetFabb, I opened Meshmixer for further editing as it has some features that I find easier to use through it than other programs. I cut the back side of the model to make it flat and therefore easier to print. I then solidified it to the maximum mesh density and solid accuracy. This makes the model rather large but this is necessary in order for it to work initially, reducing the number of polygons can always be sculpted later. Once I was satisfied with the model I exported it to a new STL file. Meshmixer View Simplify3D Using the Simplify 3D software I scaled the model I exported out of Meshmixer down to 45% so I could print a version of it quickly. I sliced the model and checked everything to be sure that there would be no major issues in printing. There were none that I could immediately notice so I printed directly from Simplify3D. Simplify3D View

Objectives -Learn more about 3D Printing and Scanning technology
-Discover how 3D Printing and Scanning assists Archeologists Audience This project is designed for grades 3-8, but can be enjoyed by anyone wanting to learn about the ways 3D printing and scanning can help the archeological field. Preparation -Students should have access to a computer with either internet access so they can log into a free TinkerCAD account, or a computer that is running other software (such as meshmixer, meshlab, etc.) that can open .STL file types.
-The "King Tut Funeral Mask" Model should be downloaded onto the students computers.
-Computer mice for each computer is recommended
-The instructor should be comfortable showing the students how to navigate the 3D space around the model in the program they choose to use for looking over the King Tut Funeral Mask model.
-For the bonus step, the students will require a mobile phone, iPod, iPad or some other smart mobile device. Step 1: Learning about Archeology Have the students learn about Archeology with a particular emphasis on its focus on the study of artifacts to learn about ancient history. Explain that often times artifacts can be fragile and difficult to handle, especially if they are very old and depending on the materials they are made of. Further, the less most artifacts can be handled, the better. Other times, artifacts have to be left where they are out of respect for the people who created them. In every case, there are times when being able to properly study and handle ancient artifacts is difficult. 3D printing and scanning technologies assist in this. Step 2: Learning about 3D Scanning Watch the Youtube Video "MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner" This video will teach a little bit about how 3D scanning works. Instruct students that this is a method Archeologists can use to get 3D computer models of artifacts from the actual artifacts themselves. 3D scanning does not harm the objects, and with some technologies the artifact never has to be moved from the site it was found at. 3D scanning can render models very accurately depending on the technology used, even mapping the actual colors and textures. Step 3: Examining a model Instruct students to open the model of King Tut's Funeral Mask on their computers. Teach them how to navigate the 3D space around the model so they can explore the model more fully. If a 3D print of the mask is available, hand it around so the students can handle it. Have the students take a closer look at certain features of the model, such as the cobra and vulture on top of the headpiece. explain that while it would be impossible for the students to be able to actually handle or view the real funeral mask (since very few people ever get the opportunity), 3D printing and scanning technology allows for models and replicas to be enjoyed by many people. It allows for study of artifacts such as King tut's funeral mask to be done without nearly as much major risk to the artifacts themselves. Step 4: Bonus Step! Using a mobile phone, download the 123D Catch application, a 3D scanning application. Provide students with an artifact and have them scan it using their mobile phones (or the phones/iPods/iPads provided to them). When the scan is finished rendering, navigate around it and see what new observations can be made using the model that were not noticed previously. 123D Catch User Guide Results At the end of this project, students should have a better understanding of how 3D printing and 3D scanning helps the archeological field of study. If the bonus step has been completed, students will have their own 3D scanned artifacts to look at. Having the knowledge of a simple, basic way to scan artifacts gives them the ability to go out and scan the world around them, increasing the number of available models to be adjusted for printing, thus preserving world artifacts for future generations to study and enjoy.

description.text: In this generator Brownian Noise is used to place blocks in a random pattern where each position has a higher probability to contain a block when the surrounding positions also contain a block. By changing the seed you can get different patterns, with the density you can increase or decrease the number of blocks. If you want to know how it works you can look here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brownian_noise Edit: Improved the script performance so higher block numbers can be generated in a reasonable time.

I modified my ZMR250 so that it can carry 2axis gimbal. You need to change the bottom and top plates and add two spacers. Arms and everything else can be used from ZMR250. You can use nearly any 2axis gimbal with this copter but I designed that specifically for my lowcost yet surprisingly good gimbal solution: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246436. Build instructions:
  • print 2x bottom plate (3.5 mm thickness)
  • print top plate (2.5 mm thickness)
  • choose some gimbal or get "my" gimbal (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246436)
  • use ZMR250 carbon arms or print any ZMR250 compatible arms
  • print two more spacers and use self-tapping screws (ZMR250 has 8 spacers, this copter needs 10 spacers)
  • use 5" propellers (6" will not fit)
    • I decided to design this copter for 5" propellers only for multiple reasons:
  • smaller difference between front and rear motors span for better balance and handling (6" would require much wider front arms)
  • according to my observations, 6" propellers usually produce significantly more vibrations which more often results in jello in the video
    • The total weight with gimbal, camera and 4S is about 850 grams. With 4S and 5045BN propellers it hovers at around 50 % of throttle and is capable to fly and handle nearly like normal ZMR250. My build setup:
  • Multistar 2206 2150kv motors
  • Gemfan 5045BN propellers
  • BlueSeries 12A ESCs
  • CC3D running Cleanflight
  • PZ0420 FPV camera
  • TS5828 600mW VTX
  • Nano-tech 4S 2200mAh 25-50 C
    • Here is some sample footage: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=roRp9UtGVRY (not all stabilized shots in this video are taken by this copter but a significant part) Enjoy and let me know about your builds :)

description.text:
Since the Apple Pencil is apparently a little fragile I created a case to store mine in. I've left a bit of space inside the tube. I did this so I could add some felt as padding. 
I've included two versions of the lid, with and without the apple logo. I've also included two versions of the bottom. The split version is helpful for anyone who might want to add a fabric lining. It allows you to apply super glue to keep the lining in place.
gcodes are for Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

I used ABS with my prints so I could sand them down and dip them in an acetone bath. Afterwards I put a few coats of white glossy spray paint on them to better match the pencil.
For the padding I cut out a rectangle of felt and wrapped it in satin. I used some felt glue secure the satin to the felt. I rolled up this combination of fabrics and super glued it to the bottom of the longer tube. I also took a tiny square of felt (about half a centimeter for both dimensions) and super glued it where the tip of the pencil would rest inside the top of the case.
The rolled up satin and felt. I recommend a thin felt, too thick and the cap might get stuck.

title: Gimbal for Xiaomi Yi / GoPro / SJCAM (2axis, forward facing)

description.text:
I designed this gimbal specifically for my modified ZMR250 quad (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246396) but it can be used for virtually any situation when you want to mount the gimbal facing forward. Camera plate will tightly fit Xiaomi YI camera (no additional fixing required) but will work well also with GoPro or SJCAM cameras (use e.g. velcro strap to fix it). I iterated over a few versions of arms and camera plates to get very good CoG balance with Xiaomi Yi. This is a lowcost (about 35 USD) but suprisingly good solution. Here is some sample footage: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=roRp9UtGVRY (not all stabilized shots in this video are taken by this copter but a significant part) There are two mounting options:
  • fixed holder (holder.stl file)
  • vibration dampened holder (dampened_holder.stl and dampened_holder_arm.stl files)
    • Parts required:
  • 2x gimbal motor (10 USD - http://www.banggood.com/Gimbal-Brushless-Motor-2208-Suitable-for-Gopro-Gimbal-p-959144.html)
  • gimbal controller (15 USD - BGC 3.1, http://www.banggood.com/BGC-3_1-2-Axis-Brushless-Gimbal-MOS-Controller-with-Mini-GY6050-Sensor-p-957358.html)
  • some servo wires
  • 300g vibration dampeners (optional - http://www.ebay.com/itm/4Pcs-300g-FPV-Gimbal-Vibration-Damping-Balls-for-Gimbals-Gopro-DJI-Quadcopter-/191605248156?hash=item2c9c90109c:g:0NMAAOSwjVVVgnqN)
    • Build instructions:
  • print holder, arm, camera plate and screw everything together :)
    • Enjoy and let me know about your builds :)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

50 %

Notes: Use ABS for printing

title: Manual Z Probe (and some code to get a servo working)

description.text:
The Prusa i3 from Prusa Reseach uses a Mini-Rambo board which does not have a connection for a servo so this is a manual Z-Probe.
BOM
1 x small micro switch the same as the Z End Stop one
1 x 3mmx20mm screw
2 x 3mm nuts or 1 x 3mm locknut
1 x small sprint 10mm long Wire in series with Z End Stop switch. For setup follow the Zennmasters videos at
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6msLOR_EfKc&list=LLhZVdzyiZNM0MAZBqKICWkw&index=3 but ignore the servo stuff. EDIT: Added some code if you really want to get a servo working on a Rambo-Mini board.
Try as I might I could not get servos working on the Rambo-Mini, turning servos on in the code disabled stepper motors. So I added an Arduino Nano board and triggered it from pin3 on the Rambo-Mini P3 connector. The Servo.ino code has comments that show what pins to use. The Prusa firmware code is patched to work with this. Also added the STL for the bracket I used. BTW, having used these mechanical probes, an Inductive probe and a Capacitive one I have settled on the capacitive probe.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Purse i3

No

20%

author: sbergmann

description.text:
For my new Printer i needed a better Spool holder.
Since i had different sizes i created a universal spool holder.
Works with Spools from 18 - 56mm Inner Diameter.
You will need 2 Bearings (select STL)
606ZZ (i: 6mm / d: 17mm / w: 6mm)
608ZZ (i: 8mm / d: 22mm / w: 7mm)
Mount on a 6/8mm Rod.
You can adjust the pressure with the M6/M8 Nut.

Print with 0% infill so the Holder will be hollow, works best with ABS/Nylon.
PLA, choose 50% since the material has not the best strenght.
use a vice to press ball bearings in to the spool holder.

Lost the ashtray years ago on my wife's Wrangler. Was doing a refresh of the interior parts (yay heat gun and Vinylex) and decided to put my printer to a "productive" use. Update 06.20.16: I adjusted the hinge pieces to fit. I used a wad of tack-it to keep the top closed. So far it's holding up to the 100+ temps here. Didn't realize the previous .stl file was v2f, but v2a is the current iteration, with the hinge pieces in the correct place. A couple of caveats...
1) My first design with 123Design, so it was a learning project for sure.
2) The extrusions designed to fit over the hinges actually miss the mark, but they're close enough to the hinge that it actually holds it in place. The top of the extrusion ends up right below the hinge.
3) Originally I was going to add an extrusion that would latch to the metal piece in the cavity that the ashtray usually snaps into, but opted it was unnecessary (see caveat #2).
